chapter.title: Installing eBox from source

tip.para: Before installing eBox from source you should be aware that the preferred installation method are the provided Debian packages, which have a much easier installation process.

chapter.para: eBox is composed of a framework and modules using it. Before installing any module you need to install the packages providing the framework, namely libebox and ebox.

Once you have installed those packages you should be able to install new modules. Anyway you should take into account that some modules may depend on another ones and you should install them in the right order
The new modules will be able to detect the paths used by the framework and will install themselves in the right place.

section.title: Getting the sources
section.para: The first thing needed to install eBox from sources is obviously the source itself. You can get it from .
You should get at least the core packages (libebox and ebox), the basic modules (objects, network and firewall) and then your desired module selection.

Once we have the gzipped tar files of the latest eBox version we should be able to start installing them. To extract the contents of a tarball you just need to run:
tar zxvf ebox-<module>-<version>.tar.gz

note.para: During the next sections will appear some commands that you should run, the ones preceded by $ should be run as a normal user and the ones preceded by # must be run as root.

section.title: Installing a basic eBox: firewall and proxy
section.para: Now we will proceed to install a basic eBox with firewall and proxy capabilities. To achieve this we should install the firewall and squid modules and every other module required by them. To get a list of dependencies for a given module you can check the INSTALL file provided in the tarball.

section.title: Installing libebox
section.para:
libebox contains some code shared by eBox client and eBox server and should always be the first package installed. Before installing it we should install every dependency that appears in the INSTALL file. We can install the packages easily using apt-get:
# apt-get install perl perl-modules sudo # apt-get install liblog-dispatch-perl liblog-log4perl-perl # apt-get install liblocale-gettext-perl libnet-ip-perl liberror-perl # apt-get install libdevel-stacktrace-perl libhtml-mason-perl gettext

The next step is to run the script configure to have it detect if everything is correctly installed and where should it install eBox. configure accepts several arguments to change its behaviour, for example, we will provide the localstatedir parameter to install variable data in a non-default directory:
$ ./configure --localstatedir=/var/

Once we have run configure we are ready to install libebox by running as root:
# make install

You can check if everything is working correctly by trying to run this command:
$ perl -MEBox -e 'print EBox::Config->version'
If it prints the eBox version then you're in the right way.

section.title: Installing eBox base
section.para:
eBox base (or just ebox) is the module that contains the framework to build eBox modules upon it and the one with the longer installation process. As usual we will check the INSTALL file for required software and will install it using apt-get:
# apt-get install apache-perl libapache-mod-perl libapache-mod-ssl # apt-get install libapache-authcookie-perl libapache-singleton-perl # apt-get install libsys-cpu-perl libsys-cpuload-perl # apt-get install libgnome2-gconf-perl libproc-process-perl

Once we have installed every requisite we can proceed to run the configure script, it will autodetect Apache and libebox, and then running make install will put everything in the right place:
$ ./configure # make install

From now on we will consider /var/lib/ebox the home directory of ebox, if you haven't used --localstatedir=/var in libebox configure, you should replace every /var/lib/ebox appearance with the output of:
$ echo $(perl -MEBox -e 'print EBox::Config->var')/lib/ebox

eBox needs unprivileged user and group in your system to run safely, so we will create the ebox user and group now. The home for the user will be /var/lib/ebox:
# addgroup --system ebox # adduser --system --home /var/lib/ebox/ --no-create-home \ --disabled-password --ingroup ebox ebox

eBox needs several directories inside its home to work properly, we will create a log directory to hold the eBox logs, a tmp to store temporary files and a gconf directory to store gconf data:
# mkdir /var/lib/ebox/tmp # mkdir /var/lib/ebox/log # mkdir /var/lib/ebox/gconf

gconf needs a .gconf.path file to know where should it store preferences for the ebox users. You must copy this file from the conf directory in the ebox sources:
# cp conf/.gconf.path /var/lib/ebox

Now we should change the owner of the /var/lib/ebox directory to the ebox user, including every subdirectory:
# chown -R ebox.ebox /var/lib/ebox/

eBox uses sudo to grant the ebox user the rights to run some commands under a privileged account, every module includes the commands that it needs to run as root. The ebox-sudoers can gather that commands from the currently installed modules and generate a correct sudoers file. Basically, every time you install a new eBox module you need to update it like this:
# ebox-sudoers > /etc/sudoers
Note that this will overwrite your /etc/sudoers file, so make a backup if you want to keep it safe.

Usually eBox takes control of every service it provides, including starting and stopping it, so the general rule is that you need to remove the links from /etc/rc2.d to avoid the services being started on system launch. The eBox base module manages apache-perl, so we will remove the links from the rc.d directories. The safer way to do this is:
# update-rc.d -f apache-perl remove
as it will work for both sysv-rc and file-rc init systems.

Now we should make sure that ebox is run on startup, a ebox init script is provided in the tools directory in the sources, we just need to copy it to /etc/init.d and run update-rc.d:
# cp tools/ebox /etc/init.d # update-rc.d ebox defaults 99

To start eBox immediately you can now run:
# /etc/init.d/ebox start
Once eBox is launched you should be able to access the administration interface at https://<ip address>/, it should like this: eBox login page

The default password is 'ebox'. It may be changed in the general configuration page. If everything works correctly you should see the eBox summary page: eBox summary page
As you will notice eBox is quite useless without installed modules so we will quickly move to the next section to install more modules that provide it nice features.

section.title: Installing eBox basic modules: network, objects and firewall
section.para: There are three modules that are required by almost every other eBox module, they are objects, network and firewall.

As usual, the first step is to install the required Debian packages:
# apt-get install dhcp3-client iproute vlan # network module # apt-get install iptables # firewall module
You should note that there are also requirements for the Linux kernel installed in the machine, it should have VLAN (for network module) and Netfilter (for firewall module) support (either built-in or with modules).

Once the prerequisites have been installed you just need to run
$ ./configure # make install
for each module. The firewall module should be the last as it depends on both objects and network module. The network module can import the current network configuration stored in /etc/network/interfaces and /etc/resolv.conf. To do it you just need to run the ebox-netcfg-import command.

Just to be sure that eBox gets the correct list of modules from gconf, you should kill every running gconfd instance:
# pkill gconf
After this you can safely run ebox-sudoers to overwrite the old sudoers file:
# ebox-sudoers > /etc/sudoers
If you point your browser to the eBox administrative interface again the new modules should appear there: eBox with the basic modules installed

section.title: Installing the HTTP proxy module
section.para:
Now we will finish our installation adding the Squid module, which provides a HTTP proxy with optional content filter. We will follow the usual procedure after reading the INSTALL file:
Install the required packages:
# apt-get install squid dansguardian
Run configure and make install:
$ ./configure # make install
Don't start the associated services on system launch:
# update-rc.d -f squid remove # update-rc.d -f dansguardian remove
Update the sudoers file:
# pkill gconf # ebox-sudoers > /etc/sudoers
After performing the previous steps, we can check if everything went ok in the eBox administrative interface, where a Squid menu entry should have appeared.

section.title: Installing LDAP modules
section.para: There are several eBox modules that use the concept of users and groups, for example, the Samba module, which allows you to setup file sharing or the mail module that provides mail accounts for users.

The module that manages users in eBox is called usersandgroups and stores them in an LDAP directory. You should install this module before any other one that requires the existance of users. As usual, this requirement will be clearly stated in the INSTALL file.

Although the installation steps are basically the same as the used to install the previous modules, there are some tricky steps in the process. In the next section we will install the usersandgroups and Samba modules.

section.title: Installing the usersandgroups module
section.para:
First of all you should perform the standard installation procedure:
# apt-get install slapd libnet-ldap-perl $ ./configure # make install # pkill gconf # ebox-sudoers > /etc/sudoers
